SourcedStatement: “It just shortens the whole timeline in which a person can lose their home,” said Brian Rees, a staff attorney at The Works Inc. nonprofit who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years. “Things (can now) happen very, very quickly.”
Name: Brian Rees
Title: staff attorney, The Works Inc.
Justification: who has represented hundreds of tenants in eviction proceedings in recent years

SourcedStatement: If the governor signed it, Henderson said, it would have “devastating” consequences for renters.
Name: Deborah Henderson
Title: Judge
Justification: who judges thousands of eviction cases per year

SourcedStatement: To Henderson, who judges thousands of eviction cases per year, the only explanation for such action was landlord lobbying.

SourcedStatement: “Landlords have always had a very strong lobbying group,” she said.

SourcedStatement: In the statement, Swann said the bill will help landlords free up apartments more quickly for the thousands of Tennesseeans seeking a home. He also said it would help the apartment industry develop new apartments, but he didn’t make clear how it would.
Name: Art Swann
Title: Sen., R-Maryville

SourcedStatement: While the difference of a week may not seem like much, Rees said it can really matter for these renters since the pathways to avoiding eviction can take time to figure out.
Name: Brian Rees
Title: staff attorney, The Works Inc.

SourcedStatement: “It’s disheartening to see them make a change that will affect families who are struggling,” Rees said.
Name: Brian Rees
Title: staff attorney, The Works Inc.

Name: Dwayne Thompson
Title: Rep., D-Cordova

SourcedStatement: Given TAR’s opposition and the legislature itself having recently moved “much farther to the right,” in his experience, Thompson said a Shelby County rental registry is “probably not in the cards, for several years anyway.”
Name: Dwayne Thompson
Title: Rep., D-Cordova

SourcedStatement: Though he’s not running for reelection, he’s hopeful whoever succeeds him will be able to find other ways to help cities deal with slumlords.
Name: Dwayne Thompson
Title: Rep., D-Cordova

SourcedStatement: While most landlords do this already, Thompson said he’s heard from tenants who tell him they have no way of contacting their landlord or property manager about maintenance issues.
Name: Dwayne Thompson
Title: Rep., D-Cordova

SourcedStatement: Still, Rees sees the legislation’s passage as a win.
Name: Brian Rees
Title: staff attorney, The Works Inc.

SourcedStatement: Because even if landlords aren’t responsive, it will provide tenants with proof they’re requesting maintenance through the proper channels — proof lawyers like Rees could theoretically use in their defense.
Name: Brian Rees
Title: staff attorney, The Works Inc.

SourcedStatement: “I really am happy to see that pass,” Rees said. “I think it’s important that tenants do have good quality contact information for their property manager or owner.”
